text.author: Pr∞fWiki
text.title: Square on Second Bimedial Straight Line applied to Rational Straight Line
text.summary1: (human1) This proof demonstrates that if AB is a second bimedial line divided at C into its medials, and DE is a rational line where DEFG = AB² is applied to DE such that DG is its breadth, then DG is a third binomial straight line.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) The proof demonstrates that if AB is a second bimedial straight line divided at point C, with AC > CB, and DEFG equals AB² applied to a rational line DE, then DG must be a third binomial straight line through geometric constructions and properties of medial, rational, and commensurable magnitudes.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) This mathematical proof demonstrates that a straight line DG, derived from applying a square equal to a second bimedial line AB to another straight line DE, is a third binomial line using classical geometric propositions related to commensurability and the properties of binomial lines.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) This mathematical proof demonstrates that a certain line DG is a third binomial straight line, deriving this result through a series of geometric and algebraic transformations and commensurability theorems.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct) The document proves DG to be a third binomial straight line through detailed geometric constructions and properties, concluding with intermediate steps showing commensurability and incommensurability relationships.
